History of AI in Healthcare

Healthcare is a system and the services that maintain and help improve people's physical health and mental well-being.

Level of AI Usage:

For the most part it is highly used in pathology, neuroscience, cardiology, oncology, and radiology. There are a few industries in healthcare that only moderately use artifical intelligence like pediatrics. This would be because kids don't need robots or chatbots tending to them, they require human connections to observe them and be around them.

Pathology:
  • Speeds up and refines tissue/cell analysis.
  • Detects diseases like leukemia in minutes.
  • Collaborations underway to ensure safety and effectiveness.
  • Used in training and education for future pathologists.

    • Neuroscience:
  • Supports treatment of stroke, Parkinson’s, and paralysis.
  • Enables home recovery via VR and brain-computer interfaces.
  • Helps restore speech by decoding brain signals.
  • Tracks eye movements to detect cognitive decline in Parkinson’s patients.

    • Cardiology:
  • Improves early detection and personalized treatment.
  • $10.5M invested by AHA in AI for heart scans and CPR.
  • Detects hidden signs of kidney/liver disease during heart scans.
  • Guides real-time CPR using wearable AI sensors.

    • Oncology:
  • Enhances accuracy in cancer detection, diagnosis, and treatment.
  • Analyzes medical images and genetic data for personalized care.
  • Predicts treatment response to optimize therapy.
  • Accelerates research by identifying patterns in large datasets.

    • Radiology:
  • Speeds up scan interpretation and improves accuracy.
  • Detects strokes and clots within minutes.
  • New frameworks help integrate AI safely into workflows.
  • Reduces burnout and improves patient outcomes.

    • Pediatrics:
  • Enhances diagnosis, record management, and communication with families.
  • Used in triage systems to prioritize care in emergencies.
  • Assists with documentation and translation for diverse patient backgrounds.
  • Research underway to detect pain in newborns using facial recognition.

    • Evolution Over Time:

    1950s–1970s: Foundations and Expert Systems

    AI was introduced as a concept by Alan Turing and formally named by John McCarthy. Early medical AI systems like INTERNIST-1 and MYCIN helped diagnose diseases and recommend treatments. These systems used rule-based logic but struggled with uncertainty and scalability.

    1980s–1990s: Digital Infrastructure & Imaging:

    AI began supporting radiologists through Computer-Aided Detection (CAD), especially in mammography. Systems like DXplain helped clinicians generate differential diagnoses. AI was also used in ECG analysis and automated blood cell counting.

    2000s–2010s: Machine Learning & Big Data:

    AI started analyzing electronic health records (EHRs) to predict hospital readmissions and disease progression. Genomic data integration enabled personalized medicine. IBM Watson gained attention for processing medical literature and assisting clinical decisions.

    2020s–Present: Deep Learning & Real-Time Applications:

    Deep learning models now outperform humans in detecting anomalies in medical imaging. Natural Language Processing (NLP) extracts insights from clinical notes and research articles. AI enhances robotic surgery, drug discovery, and remote patient monitoring. Chatbots and virtual assistants improve patient engagement and reduce administrative workload. AI is also used in telemedicine, especially post-COVID, to expand access and improve care delivery.
